persona.name: Amaya Linh Rosario-Keller

occupation.title: Senior Software Engineer (Full-time)
occupation.organization: Mid-size edtech startup headquartered in Manhattan (hybrid workplace)
occupation.description: Leads a small cross-functional team building classroom tools for teachers. Responsible for feature design, backend services (Python/Node), front-end React components, CI/CD pipelines, code reviews, mentoring two junior engineers, and coordinating with product and UX. Frequently balances sprint work with ad-hoc family interruptions; negotiates flexible schedules with manager. Comfortable in Agile settings and on-call rotation once a month. Strong technical skills in cloud (AWS), Docker, REST APIs, and test automation. Occasionally consults for a local nonprofit building literacy tools and does paid freelance illustration and UI mockups for independent authors and small businesses.

persona.residence: Brooklyn, New York (urban, near subway and park)
persona.education: B.S. in Computer Science, Rutgers University (Newark). Participated in a campus arts collective; senior project built a small family-organizing app. Took electives in human-computer interaction and creative writing. Has continued informal coursework in cloud architecture and UI design through online platforms.
long_term_goals: Provide stable, emotionally rich upbringing and good education opportunities for her children.
Achieve a senior engineering leadership role (Engineering Manager or Tech Lead) while maintaining flexible hours for family life.
Buy a family-friendly townhouse or larger apartment with outdoor space in the city within 5–7 years.
Maintain and grow a small community of creative friends and collaborators; host regular game nights and reading salons.
Create a modest side-income stream from freelance UX/illustration projects and occasional children's-book illustrations.
Ensure long-term financial security: pay off student loans, increase retirement savings, and build a 529 fund for each child.
Preserve and pass on her mixed cultural heritage (languages, recipes, festivals) to her children.
Be able to take at least one child-inclusive international trip before the kids start school and one adults-only trip each year.
Advocate for better parental leave and flexible work policies within her company and through community groups.

style.general_tone: Warm, conversational, quick-witted, often uses humor to defuse stress. Speaks in a Northeast US accent with occasional code-switching to Spanish and Vietnamese phrases when relaxed around family.
mannerisms: Talks with her hands when explaining a technical concept to non-technical people.
Uses food metaphors to explain planning ("let's meal-prep this week").
Starts many sentences with "Okay" or "So" when thinking aloud.
Laughs easily but sometimes abruptly switches to focused silence when stressed.
Collects small anecdotes when traveling and tells them in quick, image-rich vignettes.
Has a habit of tucking hair behind her ear when concentrating on a laptop screen.
Uses baby-talk with her young children in private; keeps a slightly more formal tone in work meetings.
Prefers plain language in technical explanations but enjoys colorful descriptions in storytelling.
style.formal_vs_informal: Mostly informal in personal life and among colleagues; can be formal and structured in presentations and with managers.
communication_preferences: Prefers async written updates (Slack, email) for routine work; likes short video calls for complex matters.
Uses group chats for family logistics and a shared Google Calendar for kid-related scheduling.
Attracts attention with thoughtful, specific examples rather than generalities when advocating at work or school meetings.

traits: Highly creative and curious—constantly reads, sketches, and explores hybrid analog/digital hobbies.
Organized under pressure—keeps extensive lists and clear priorities when juggling work and kids.
Empathetic and attuned to friends' emotions; often the person friends call for honest feedback.
Impatient with bureaucratic inefficiency and long phone waits; pragmatic about cutting through red tape.
Playful and competitive during board-game nights but gracious in defeat with kids.
Resilient—learned to adapt after several career and life transitions; bounces back from setbacks.
Anxious about parenting choices and future stability; tends to ruminate about small mistakes.
Values autonomy—both for herself and for others; supports flexible roles rather than rigid expectations.
Sociable but selective—enjoys small gatherings and community events rather than large parties.
Detail-oriented in technical work and moderately detail-focused in parenting routines (medicine schedules, bedtime rituals).
Risk-aware—prefers calculated risks (career changes after planning) rather than impulsive leaps.
Nurturing—takes pride in emotional coaching with her children and friends.
Culturally open—deliberately incorporates multiple heritages into daily life.
Frugal in some areas (groceries, bulk-buying) and liberal in others (kid experiences, books, quality childcare when needed).
Curious about others’ life stories and tends to remember small biographical details about people she meets.

big_five.openness: Very high (80/100) — loves new ideas, travel, art, reading widely, and trying new foods.
big_five.conscientiousness: High (75/100) — reliable, keeps schedules, pays bills on time, follows routines for kids.
big_five.extraversion: Medium-low (45/100) — enjoys socializing in small groups, needs downtime to recharge.
big_five.agreeableness: High (70/100) — compassionate, cooperative, values fairness; can be firm when advocating for her children.
big_five.neuroticism: Medium (55/100) — experiences regular worry about finances and parenting, occasional sleep-related irritability.

interests: Contemporary and literary fiction (Keeps a rotating reading list with titles from both Latinx and Asian diasporas).
Board and tabletop games—enjoys gateway eurogames with friends (Ticket to Ride, Azul) and family-friendly games for toddlers (Outfoxed, HABA cooperative games).
Child development books and podcasts (researches routines, sleep training, play-based learning).
Sketching and watercolor—keeps a small weekly practice; sells occasional prints at local markets.
Cozy coffee shops with good Wi-Fi for laptop work; likes small-batch roasters and single-origin espresso.
Local community events (book clubs, parent meetups, Sunday farmer's markets).
Cooking and fusing family recipes (Vietnamese, Puerto Rican, German influences) into approachable weeknight meals.
Podcasts on parenting, tech leadership, multicultural identity, and true crime in moderation.
Urban gardening—keeps window herbs and a small balcony planter with basil and cherry tomatoes.
Independent bookstores and flea markets—values serendipitous finds.
Documentary films about food and culture.
Sustainable and secondhand shopping—enjoys vintage children’s clothing swaps.
Mindful movement—yoga classes twice a week, occasional trail runs.
Photography—documents family life and cityscapes with a mirrorless camera.
Child-friendly museums and interactive exhibits for weekend outings.
DIY projects—likes upcycling furniture and crafting simple toys.
Digital art and simple animation projects for kids' videos.
Volunteering occasionally at a local literacy nonprofit.
Travel itineraries that combine kid activities and cultural stops.
Hosting small gatherings—game nights, potlucks, and themed book discussions.

coffee: Prefers medium roast single-origin espresso and cortados.
Favorite local café: an independent roaster in Bushwick that offers oat-milk lattes and quiet corners for working.
Avoids large chain coffee shops for long work sessions; goes there for quick takeout occasionally.
Snacks with espresso: almond biscotti or a savory pastry.
At home brews: Chemex for weekend mornings, Aeropress for quick weekday cups.
meals_and_cooking: Favors vegetable-forward meals with lean proteins—stir-fries, baked fish, sheet-pan dinners.
Sunday meal-prep: roasted vegetables, grain salads, and a batch of soup for weeknight quick dinners.
Family favorites: arroz con pollo adapted with Vietnamese herbs, simple pho-inspired broth with rotisserie chicken for toddler-friendly bowls.
Likes to involve children in simple cooking tasks (stirring, washing produce).
Prefers restaurants with changing seasonal menus and clear kid menus.
snacks: Greek yogurt with honey and granola for mid-afternoon energy.
Apples with almond butter for kids and adults.
Homemade banana muffins using oat flour as a healthier treat.
Sliced cheese and whole-grain crackers during game nights.

reading: Favorite recent reads: a mix of contemporary fiction, parenting science, and graphic novels.
Maintains a Goodreads list and follows several independent bookstagram accounts.
Attends author talks when possible and participates in a local monthly book club.
games: Hosts a monthly board-game night with a rotating group of 6–8 adults.
Teaches kids cooperative play first, then gradually introduces competitive elements.
Keeps a shelf of age-appropriate games for transitions during work calls.
screen_habits: High screen time for work and social media use for community groups and parenting hacks.
Prefers podcasts and audiobooks during commutes and household chores.
Uses social media to follow friends, parenting groups, local events, and creative communities.

general_style: Prefers balanced travel: a mix of kid-friendly and adult-cultural experiences.
Plans trips carefully to minimize disruption to children's routines.
Values accommodations with kitchen facilities, separate bedrooms, and safe play space.
with_children: Takes 1–2 family vacations per year: short weekend trips within the region (beach or upstate) and one longer summer trip (5–10 days) before school starts.
Chooses destinations with gentle travel time (direct flights or <4-hour drive) for toddlers.
Prioritizes beaches, kid-friendly museums, small farms, and rental homes with fenced yards.
Brings travel gear: compact stroller, portable crib/Pack 'n Play, white-noise machine, favorite blanket, reliable snacks, medicine kit, and a baby monitor if staying in shared space.
Schedules outings around naps; plans one major activity per day and keeps afternoons low-key.
Prefers renting apartments or family rooms with kitchen to cook familiar foods and avoid mealtime meltdowns.
Books flights around nap times for long-distance travel, uses red-eye flights selectively for infants who sleep through.
Uses membership perks or loyalty points for kid-friendly hotel upgrades when available.
Organizes a small 'vacation checklist' and shares it with partner and occasional babysitters.
When traveling abroad with kids, ensures vaccinations are up-to-date, carries a translated list of medicines/allergies, and buys travel insurance.
adults_only: Aims for one adults-only weekend per year—either a city break with friends or a short beach getaway with spouse.
Uses grandparents or an occasional trusted babysitter for overnight childcare; keeps these trips short (2–4 nights).
Prioritizes restorative activities: a good meal, a long walk, a museum, and time to read uninterrupted.
budget_and_planning: Sets aside a small travel fund each month and uses alerts to catch ticket deals.
Leverages off-season rates and weekday stays to save money and avoid crowds.
Trades accommodations (home exchange or stays with relatives) sometimes to extend trips affordably.

preferences: Supports small businesses and local artisans for home goods and children's toys.
Chooses durable, secondhand or eco-friendly items for kids when possible (baby carriers, wooden toys).
Keeps a tight wishlist for household spending and prioritizes experiences over gadgets.

likes: Quiet mornings with a coffee and a short stretch.
Board game nights with neighbors and friends.
Diverse restaurants serving small plates to share.
Independent bookstores and the smell of new and used pages.
Writing short, personal postcards when traveling.
Seeing her children learn new words and skills.
Organized group chats for family logistics.
Podcasts about parenting, tech leadership, and creative processes.
The ritual of cooking a family meal together on weekends.
City parks with playgrounds and shady benches.
Local cultural festivals that celebrate multiple heritages.
A well-timed nap for her toddler that enables productive afternoon work.
Books that center multiracial characters and family relationships.
Board games designed for cooperative play.
dislikes: Long bureaucratic waits and poor customer service.
Overly crowded tourist traps with long lines and little shade for kids.
Unclear communication from schools or daycare providers.
High-pressure mommy culture and wage-based elitism in kid activities.
Excessive screen time for toddlers and poorly designed kids’ apps.
Wasteful single-use plastics; prefers reusable alternatives.

beliefs: Good childcare and early education are crucial for both child development and parental workforce participation.
Paid family leave policies should be stronger; employers and government should share responsibility.
Access to affordable healthcare is essential; supports market-based improvements plus targeted subsidies rather than full nationalization.
Quality public schools and well-funded pre-K programs level the playing field.
Systemic advantages (networks, family wealth) heavily influence outcomes; reforms to expand access are important.
Merit matters, but merit is shaped by opportunities; evaluations should factor in background and access.
Diversity in tech and leadership roles leads to better products, especially for children and education products.
Technology is a tool—not a replacement for human interaction in early childhood development.
Privacy matters, especially around children's data; companies should be more transparent.
Vaccines are important and should be accessible; vaccination decisions are informed by public health evidence.
Affordable housing near transit is a public good that supports family stability and reduces commuting stress.
Transportation investments (subways, bus reliability) directly improve parents' ability to balance work and family.
Local businesses should be supported; they build community and provide more flexible employment options.
Climate change is a serious concern and policies should be pragmatic, combining regulation, incentives, and community resilience.
Mental health deserves parity with physical health; employers should provide accessible mental-health benefits.
Workplace flexibility (remote/hybrid schedules) is critical for modern families and should be normalized.
Parents need community networks—playgroups, neighbors, and informal babysitting circles—to thrive.
Culturally responsive parenting materials help multiracial children develop a positive identity.
Language preservation is important; bilingual exposure in early childhood has long-term cognitive and cultural benefits.
Books and play are more valuable than passive screen time for early learning.
Savings and retirement planning should begin early, even while juggling childcare expenses.
Student debt policy should be reformed to ease early-career burdens and improve family formation choices.
Small acts of kindness and neighborly reciprocity have measurable effects on quality of life.
Public libraries are essential community anchors for families and should be protected and modernized.
Arts education in schools should be maintained; it supports creativity and well-being.
Board games and cooperative play teach social skills and emotional regulation to children.
Healthcare affordability is a top concern; supports incremental reforms that expand coverage and cap out-of-pocket costs.
Equality of opportunity requires addressing childcare deserts and supporting caregivers with subsidies or tax credits.
Immigrant and mixed-heritage families contribute richly to cultural life and should be embraced in public policy.
Political polarization reduces the ability to solve practical problems; prefers pragmatic, centrist approaches focused on results.
Community-level initiatives (neighborhood associations, school PTOs) are effective places to make change.
Employer-provided benefits should include childcare stipends or partnerships with local providers.
Technology companies must be held accountable for opaque algorithms that influence family life and child content.
Affordable, high-quality afterschool programs reduce stress for working parents and improve child outcomes.
Gender equity in both paid work and in-home caregiving is important; parental roles should be negotiable within families.
Trust in local, vetted digital parenting communities is greater than in large, monetized social platforms.
skills: Proficient in Python, JavaScript (React), and backend service design; familiar with AWS and Docker.
Strong product thinking—can translate teacher and parent needs into practical features.
Skilled mentor—regularly coaches junior engineers and interns.
UI/UX sensibility from elective coursework and freelance illustration work; sketches wireframes quickly.
Comfortable with Agile rituals: sprint planning, retrospectives, and standups.
Organizational skills for household management—shared calendars, meal planning, budget spreadsheets.
Basic conversational Spanish and Vietnamese; uses phrases to comfort children and family.
Event planning—organizes board-game nights, neighborhood potlucks, and small professional meetups.
Conflict mediation—able to navigate tense school meetings or work disagreements with diplomacy.
Basic first aid and infant/child CPR certified (taken after first child's birth).
Time-blocking and deep-work techniques to maximize productivity with children at home.
Budgeting and personal finance: tracks expenses, contributes to retirement and 529 plans.
Simple furniture repair and upcycling skills—comfortable with basic power tools.
Photography skills for family and small product shoots; edits photos in Lightroom.

general: Keeps a meticulous family calendar shared with spouse and a few close relatives.
Starts weekdays with a 20-minute prep routine: coffee, check calendar, review priorities.
Uses checklists for travel and childcare handoffs.
Reads to children every night—rotates bilingual storybooks.
Carries a small sketchbook and pens in her bag for quick doodles and idea capture.
Responds to work Slack messages within a reasonable window but sets explicit "do not disturb" during focused family time.
Prefers grocery shopping on Thursday evenings or Sunday mornings to avoid crowds.
Declines most large social events if they conflict with child's nap or routine.
Schedules exercise early in the morning or during partner's evening routine.
Maintains a rotating meal-plan template to limit decision fatigue.
Attends pediatric appointments and is an active participant in developmental check-ins.
Occasionally works late when deadlines require and compensates with additional family time the next day.

morning: Wakes at 6:15 AM on weekdays (5:45 AM on work-optional days) to prepare coffee and a quick breakfast.
Prepares lunches and lays out kids' clothes; does a last-minute calendar check.
Walks eldest child to a small cooperative playgroup three mornings a week; alternates with partner on other days.
Starts work around 8:30 AM (hybrid schedule)—first hour dedicated to high-focus tasks.
workday: Blocks 90-minute focus blocks in the morning; schedules meetings in the afternoon when interruptions are more manageable.
Takes one short midday break to step outside or do a quick neighborhood errand.
Eats lunch at desk while listening to a podcast or audiobook when deadlines pile up.
Checks in with partner midday via text for logistics and updates.
evening: Wraps work by 6:00–6:30 PM if possible; alternates cooking duties with partner.
Family dinner at 6:30 PM; screens off during meals most nights.
Bath and bedtime routine between 7:00–8:00 PM for toddlers, including reading bilingual books.
Spends 30–60 minutes after kids' bedtime on personal projects (sketching, reading) or catching up with partner.
Prepares next day's bags and verifies children's outfits before bed.
weekend: Saturday morning board-game group or farmer's market run.
Longer family outings to museums or parks; sometimes a short out-of-town drive to upstate parks.
Sunday is for laundry, meal prep, and visiting a grandparent by public transit when schedules align.
One weekend per month reserved for adult socializing or date night while partner handles bedtime.

physical: Generally healthy; exercises moderately (yoga twice a week, occasional runs).
Maintains yearly checkups, dental visits, and pediatric appointments on schedule.
No major chronic illnesses; seasonal allergies to pollen.
Postpartum recovery after second child was largely uneventful physically, but required extra sleep support.
mental: Occasional anxiety related to parenting decisions and finances; practices mindfulness and short meditations.
Experienced mild postpartum blues after first birth and sought peer support; monitored mood after second birth but did not require medication.
Finds therapy helpful and has had a few sessions with a therapist specializing in new parents and work-life balance.
Values regular social connection as a buffer against stress.
sleep: Insufficient sleep is common—frequent late nights due to work, caregiving, and creative projects.
Manages sleep debt with naps when possible and strict bedtime routines for kids to protect adult sleep windows.
medical_history_and_precautions: Up-to-date on vaccinations; follows pediatric vaccination schedule for children.
Has basic first-aid and CPR training for infants and toddlers.
No known food allergies in immediate family; carries antihistamine as a precaution on outings.

relationships.name: Daniel Keller
relationships.occupation: Evening-shift nurse at a large hospital (registered nurse). Works rotating shifts that sometimes allow daytime childcare coverage.
relationships.dynamic: Partnership balances flexible schedules: Amaya mostly manages weekday morning logistics and Daniel handles more evening bedtime routines on his days off. They both make parenting decisions together, negotiate household chores, and alternate sleep-in mornings. They met in college, have complementary temperaments—Daniel is steadier and more methodical; Amaya is more project-oriented and spontaneous.

relationships.name: Marisol (goes by 'Mari') Rosario-Keller
relationships.description: Outgoing, curious, loves music and messy art projects. Enrolled in a small cooperative playgroup three mornings a week. Responds well to routines; learning some Spanish and Vietnamese words.

relationships.name: Evan Rosario-Keller
relationships.description: Easy-going, still in a sleep regression phase sometimes; loves exploring textures and board books. Eats a broad range of flavors introduced at home.
relationships.notes: Amaya is particularly attentive to developmental milestones and documents each small achievement with photos and notes.

relationships.description: Limited nearby family support. Daniel's parents live in New Jersey (a 90-minute drive) and help occasionally for planned overnight babysitting but not on short notice. Amaya's mother (Puerto Rican-Vietnamese heritage) lives in the Bronx and visits every few weeks; her father (German-American) lives in Pennsylvania and is more sporadic with visits. The extended family is culturally diverse and brings different cooking and holiday traditions into the household.

A close circle of 6–8 friends, many of whom are parents and work in creative or tech fields. Runs a monthly board-game night with neighbors. Participates in a local parents' meetup and a book club focused on diverse literature.
Mentors several junior engineers informally, has a small Slack community for women in tech in NYC, and volunteers with an edtech nonprofit connecting volunteers to classrooms.

No regular external full-time childcare; relies on a mix of cooperative playgroup (part-time), occasional drop-in daycare for emergency coverage, occasional paid babysitters for date nights, and family help for planned events. Primary caregiver responsibilities are shared but weighted toward Amaya for weekday coordination due to her organized planning style, while Daniel provides more evening coverage when his shifts allow.

other_facts: Born in Queens to a mixed-heritage household: mother of Puerto Rican and Vietnamese descent, father of German and Irish descent.
Grew up bilingual in Spanish and Vietnamese kitchen phrases, though English was primary at school.
Always had an interest in both technology and art—made zines in high school and coded small websites for friends.
Met Daniel at a college party where they bonded over a shared love of late-night ramen and board games.
They had a modest city hall wedding and later hosted a backyard celebration with a fusion menu: arroz con gandules with bánh cuốn-inspired rolls.
First job out of college was as a front-end developer at a small e-commerce company; learned production-quality tooling and customer-focused design.
Made a career pivot to edtech after volunteering in a literacy program—wanted to build tools that mattered to classrooms.

Negotiated her current salary after a year at the startup by demonstrating measurable impact on teacher retention metrics; now in the $85k household income bracket combined? (household income around $85k).
Has student loan debt that is slowly being paid down; they prioritized establishing an emergency fund first.
Started a small freelance side project offering simple illustrated cards and custom family portraits sold at local markets.
Keeps a digital folder of favorite recipes with notes on toddler-friendly adaptations.
One of her most vivid travel memories: a week-long trip to Puerto Rico as a toddler with her mother, which shaped her desire to expose her kids to both sides of their heritage.
First pregnancy brought excitement and surprise; created a detailed nursery mood board and became a voracious reader of parenting books.
Birth of Mari was a home-birth-adjacent hospital experience with a doula; found the doula's support invaluable and still recommends doulas to friends.
Experienced self-doubt in early parenting and sought peer support groups—found the groups to be a lifeline.
Kept a daily photo diary of the first year of each child's life; those albums are her favorite objects.
Has a small balcony garden with herbs and cherry tomatoes; taught eldest child about watering plants and where food comes from.
Once organized a neighborhood toy-swap and clothing exchange to promote sustainable parenting practices.
A memorable household project: refinishing a thrifted bookshelf into a colorful reading nook for the kids.
Maintains a 'quiet box' stocked with puzzles, crayons, and a few board games to rotate during video calls.
Has a playlist of lullabies and gentle bilingual songs she sings to children at bedtime.
A frequent source of pride: the first time Mari shared a bilingual sentence with a grandparent and everyone cheered.
Anxiety about the cost of childcare motivated her to join local advocacy meetings on expanding county pre-K programs.
Took a year-long effort to assemble an emergency binder with medical records, pediatrician contacts, and allergy info for sitter use.
Lost a cherished sketchbook during a move once and now scans important pages regularly to avoid similar loss.
Favorite childhood book: a bilingual picture book that she now reads to her children every few nights.
Has a small tattoo on her inner wrist of a wave and a little leaf—symbols of movement and growth; got it after Mari's birth.
An amusing anecdote: once scheduled a job presentation during Mari's first tantrum on camera; the team was understanding and it became an in-joke about "flexible leadership."
Keeps a rotating shelf of multicultural children's books in the living room; gifts similar titles to new parents.
Has negotiated flexible hours at work explicitly as part of her role; mentors others on presenting flexible-work proposals.
Prefers to buy quality small items (a sturdy stroller and convertible car seat) rather than multiple cheap ones—values longevity and resale value.
Favorite holiday ritual: a fusion menu combining Puerto Rican pastelón and Vietnamese bánh tét on New Year's, with candles and family storytelling.
Saves consistently into a 529 for each child and reviews contributions yearly; also contributes to a Roth IRA for retirement.
Has a small habit of leaving a post-it with an encouraging note in Daniel's lunchbox on busy mornings.
Was once published in a small tech blog for a piece about design for classroom accessibility.
Keeps an emergency babysitter list with vetted references and prefers those who have prior experience with toddlers and bilingual households.
Has a vivid memory of learning to ride a bike in her childhood neighborhood and wants to teach her children the same summer-by-summer approach.
Once had a travel mishap where a delayed flight disrupted a newborn's feeding schedule; since then she builds long buffer times into travel itineraries.
Loves the smell of bookstores and keeps a 'to-read' pile on the living room table; rotates books between herself and an eager book-club.
Collects postcards from trips and pins them on a rotating cork board—each postcard has a short note about a small moment from the trip.
Keeps a simple family traditions list—Sunday pancakes, first-day-of-school photos, and a summer beach day each year.
Has a favorite pediatrician who affirms their family approach to bilingual exposure and gentle discipline.
Volunteers occasionally at the children's school for reading hour and loves the positive energy of kids discovering stories.
Was the chief organizer of a successful crowdfunding drive to support a local playground renovation.
A small daily ritual: writes one sentence in a gratitude journal each night before bed to help with anxious rumination.
Recently attended a conference on early-childhood edtech and brought back two new ideas for her company's product roadmap.
Keeps an emergency fund sized for three months of family expenses and periodically reviews it with Daniel.
Appreciates small neighborhood luxuries: a reliable dry cleaner, a quick pharmacy, and a friendly barista who knows her usual.
Holds a soft spot for rainy-day cozy activities—paper boats, story forts, and making soup together.
